skill.name: xlsx
skill.description: Comprehensive Excel spreadsheet creation, editing, and analysis with support for formulas, formatting, charts, data analysis, and visualization. Use when working with .xlsx, .xlsm, .csv files for: (1) Creating spreadsheets with formulas and formatting, (2) Reading/analyzing data, (3) Modifying existing spreadsheets while preserving formulas, (4) Creating charts and visualizations, (5) Data transformation and analysis, (6) Multi-worksheet operations
skill.summary: Comprehensive Excel spreadsheet creation, editing, and analysis with support for formulas, formattin...
skill.author: AutumnsGrove

security_audit.summary: This is a pure spreadsheet manipulation skill using openpyxl and pandas libraries. No network calls, no command execution, no sensitive file access. File operations are limited to user-specified Excel paths only.

content.value_statement: Manual spreadsheet tasks waste time and introduce errors. This skill automates Excel file creation, editing, analysis, and visualization with formulas, charts, and formatting. It handles .xlsx, .xlsm, and .csv files for any data workflow.
actual_capabilities: Create new Excel workbooks with headers, data, and formulas
Read and edit existing .xlsx and .xlsm files while preserving formulas
Apply cell formatting including fonts, colors, borders, and number formats
Create charts (line, bar, pie, scatter, area) with titles and legends
Add conditional formatting with color scales and data bars
Convert between CSV and Excel formats with pandas integration
limitations: Cannot read or edit legacy .xls files (Excel 97-2003 format)
Charts are limited to supported openpyxl types (line, bar, pie, scatter, area)
Does not create or modify Excel macros (.xlsm macro execution not supported)

use_cases.title: Generate financial reports
use_cases.description: Create income statements, balance sheets, and profit reports with dynamic formulas that auto-calculate totals and margins.

use_cases.title: Transform and analyze data
use_cases.description: Convert CSV files to formatted Excel reports with pivot tables, summary statistics, and data visualizations.

use_cases.title: Build executive dashboards
use_cases.description: Design multi-chart dashboards with KPIs, trend lines, and formatted summary metrics for presentations.

prompt_templates.title: Basic spreadsheet
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Excel workbook with columns for Product, Q1 Sales, Q2 Sales, Q3 Sales, Q4 Sales, and Total. Add sample data for 5 products. Add formulas to calculate quarterly totals in the Total column.

prompt_templates.title: With formatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a formatted sales report with blue header row, bold text, currency formatting, and auto-fitted column widths. Add a pie chart showing sales distribution by product.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-sheet
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a multi-worksheet workbook with separate sheets for Q1, Q2, Q3, and Q4 sales data. Add an Annual Summary sheet that references each quarterly sheet to calculate yearly totals.

prompt_templates.title: Conditional format
prompt_templates.description: Apply conditional formatting to highlight cells with values above target, use data bars for visual comparison, and add color scales to show performance trends.

output_examples.input: Create a sales report with product names in column A, monthly sales in columns B through E, and formulas for quarterly totals.
output: Applied bold blue headers to row 1
Added SUM formulas in column F for each product
Formatted currency values in columns B through F
Auto-fitted all columns to fit content

best_practices: Use Excel formulas instead of Python calculations so values update when source data changes.
Load large files in read_only mode for better performance and lower memory usage.
Preserve existing formulas by not using data_only=True when editing workbooks.
anti_patterns: Do not use data_only=True when editing files if formulas need to be preserved.
Avoid cell-by-cell operations in loops for large datasets; use ws.append() instead.
Do not load entire large files into memory; use read_only mode and process row by row.

faq.question: What Excel file formats does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill supports .xlsx and .xlsm files for reading and writing. It also reads and writes .csv files through pandas integration.

faq.question: What are the limits for file size?
faq.answer: openpyxl handles files up to system memory limits. For files over 100MB, use read_only or write_only mode for optimal performance.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with other data tools?
faq.answer: Yes, pandas integration enables reading/writing DataFrames. You can combine with SQL databases, JSON files, and other data sources.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only accesses files you explicitly specify by path. No data is sent to external servers. All operations are local.

faq.question: Why are my formulas showing as text?
faq.answer: Ensure formulas do not start with a quote character. Use ws['A1'] = '=SUM(B1:B10)' not ws['A1'] = "'=SUM(B1:B10)".

faq.question: How does this compare to xlsxwriter?
faq.answer: openpyxl can read and edit existing files while xlsxwriter only creates new files. openpyxl is better for modifications while xlsxwriter excels at rich formatting.
